channel.title: DuckSquack
channel.description: Essays on AI, Technology & Society by Tim Hughes

item.title: The Fixed Point
item.description: Reflects on world models and the strange loop where matter arranges itself into configurations that simulate the physics that produced it. Intelligence as the universe comprehending itself.

item.title: The Rustle in the Grass
item.description: A fifteen-year follow-up finding that warning signs have intensified and patterns of imperial decline have become more pronounced.

item.title: The Widening Gyre
item.description: Examines the growing divide between AI insiders and outsiders, warning that the gap in tacit knowledge compounds daily and may become unbridgeable.

item.title: Teaching Arthur
item.description: A father's curriculum for his son: practical skills, critical thinking, kindness with boundaries, and the lesson that you are stronger than you believe.

item.title: The Meaning Void
item.description: Asks what happens to meaning when work disappears, suggesting the answer may involve returning to older sources of identity: community, presence, and local contribution.

item.title: The Loneliness Dividend
item.description: Explores how loneliness has become an industry, with AI companions as the latest product that addresses the symptom while leaving the underlying causes untouched.

item.title: Digital Sovereignty
item.description: Examines Australia's dependence on foreign-controlled digital infrastructure, asking what sovereignty means when critical systems are owned by others.

item.title: The Chronic Patient and the Algorithm
item.description: Fifteen years of healthcare system failures examined through the lens of chronic illness, exploring how AI might fix informational failures while human presence remains irreplaceable.

item.title: The Last Normal Tuesday
item.description: Examines Australia's housing bubble, manufacturing collapse, and AI-driven job displacement, arguing that unprecedented economic disruption is imminent.

item.title: A Prosthetic for Empathy
item.description: Explores what happens when AI moves beyond imitating love to understanding its shape, and whether machines can extend human connection.

item.title: Escape Velocity
item.description: Argues that China has achieved structural advantages in AI development through manufacturing dominance, energy capacity, and civil-military integration that may prove insurmountable.

item.title: The System is Already Dead
item.description: A personal account of navigating systemic failure through chronic illness, arguing we must build for continuity rather than recovery.

item.title: What Does Australia Actually Make?
item.description: Catalogues Australia's manufacturing collapse and strategic vulnerabilities, arguing we have become a mine with a housing bubble attached through deliberate policy failure.

item.title: Sandpapering Our Structural Decay
item.description: Critiques Australia's misplaced priorities, comparing national outrage over cricket cheating to indifference toward economic decline and squandered natural resources.

item.title: Parenthood in the Age of Super Intelligence
item.description: Reflects on becoming a father during the AI revolution, exploring how to prepare a child for a world where traditional education and work are being transformed.

item.title: After Scarcity, Mastery
item.description: Envisions a post-scarcity future where survival is automated and meaning is found in craft and excellence for its own sake. Proposes the foundations needed: closed-loop manufacturing, peace infrastructure, and stable capital.

item.title: Reverse Engineering Nature's Quantum
item.description: Explores how quantum phenomena already pervade biology, suggesting we are catching up to computational processes that have existed for billions of years.

item.title: Navigating the MAD MAP: Mutual Assured Destruction vs. Mutual Assured Prosperity
item.description: Presents two possible AI futures: Mutual Assured Destruction through conflict and fragmentation, or Mutual Assured Prosperity through cooperation.

item.title: The Inheritance Cliff
item.description: Examines how parental wealth has become the primary determinant of home ownership in Australia, arguing we have constructed a de facto aristocracy while maintaining democratic forms.

item.title: The Death of the Junior Role
item.description: Argues that AI is eliminating entry-level positions across professions, severing the apprenticeship pipeline through which expertise has traditionally been transmitted.

item.title: The Rerun of Rome
item.description: A 2011 essay comparing American structural patterns to late Rome: currency debasement, military overextension, infrastructure decay, and declining civic virtue.
